More probably, though, the sun shone instead. The sky would have been very indifferent. It was not a large gathering bunched at the graveside, silent. Max Brod, humped and intent, gave the one speech, a lament, a claim, an honouring. The box was ready to go, Kafka Iat last/becominglthe mole he always felt he was, to steal along the winding tunnels of his secret castle, or to burrow as he used to, furled under his sick man\u2019s bedclothes, still and safe, and see himself sail his books away adventuring into the real and difficult world. The distraction when it came am o Pe-rc came from that world, a woman, dark, ^Cl11 1 1 Ulll llldL uUllUj a YVUlliCllI, UdlIYjV twenj^sh, who broke decorum, and in the shock y / ' y of a moment\u2019s numb surprise, flung hair, arms, body and passionate wailing in a wild restraining struggle over the gaping trench. Kafka\u2019s father 38 fr$ &ee«»vu*v<; } < \n￼turned his wide back. Someone or other helped her, bent to her trembling shoulders, lent her a kind of calm, and the spent tears dried on her cheek. The itch of them she would wince away from even when her small name slid from sight, and her rich hair paled, and the man that she thought she held hers only was everyone\u2019s. These two had fused and faded. Soon his dark books would glow in a space whirling at some indefinite distance from that agonised, now more or less irrelevant, Prague afternoon.
